Award.AwardTitle: Gordon Research Seminar and Gordon Research Conference on Cellular and Molecular Fungal Biology

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will support attendance of young faculty, under-represented minority scientists, PUI faculty, along with graduate students and post-docs at the 2018 Cellular and Molecular Fungal Biological Gordon Research Seminar and Conference to be held in Holderness, NH June 16-22, 2018. The meeting will consist of short talks, poster sessions, communal dining, and conversations that will provide ample opportunity for sharing latest research results and for exploring collaborative possibilities.

Fungi display an incredible diversity of forms and functions; they are master recyclers of nutrients in natural ecosystems, devastating pathogens of humans, animals, and plant crops, and superb chassis for synthetic biology. The Broader Impacts of this project involves both the importance of the topic to our understanding of cellular and molecular biology as a whole, as well as the training of new scientists to pursue research in this important and industrially relevant field. Sessions will be developed to specifically provide opportunities for young researchers to present and receive constructive feedback on their work. The primary purposes of this conference are to promote discussion between scientists with common professional interests, including those from non-research-intensive colleges and universities, to facilitate the exchange of ideas across disciplines, and to catalyze the pursuit of new scientific collaborations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goals of the 2018 Gordon Research Seminar and Gordon Research Conference on Cellular and Molecular Fungal Biology were to (i) bring together, and promote networking between researchers who study fungi at all career stages, (ii) assess our current understanding of diverse areas of fungal research in a setting that promotes open and frank exchange of data, hypotheses and ideas between investigators from diverse disciplines and research backgrounds, and (iii) actively develop the next generation of research leaders in fungal biology via explicit mentoring and networking programs.

Both meetings were highly successful and received high marks from all participants. A total of 62 graduate students and postdocs attended the first-ever Gordon Research Seminar (GRS). A total of 175 researchers (half of which were graduate students and postdocs) attended the Gordon Research Conference (GRC). Both the GRS and GRC exceeded site capacity and were sell-out events. As evidenced in both GRS and GRC programs, both meetings brought a remarkably diverse group of investigators and promoted networking between early career investigators and world leading investigators. The gender balance in attendees, speakers and session chairs in both meetings was 50%-50%. There were participants from 6 different continents and from 24 different countries around the world.

Both meetings featured a wide diversity of research topics in fungal biology, ranging from molecular, cellular and synthetic, to organismal, and evolutionary. Each talk was accompanied by an extended period of questions and answers (typically 10 minutes) as well as by additional discussions and conversations during meal times, poster sessions, and free time.

To actively develop the next generation of research leaders in fungal biology via explicit mentoring and networking programs, this project aided the establishment, funding and running the first ever GRS. The 2018 GRS meeting was organized by graduate students and postdocs (Dr. Dana Opulente, a postdoc at the University of Wisconsin and Mr. Brad Bartholomai, a graduate student at Dartmouth were the chairs) and was only open to them. The GRS organizers invited a mentoring committee of distinguished leaders of our field, who served as mentors not just during the GRS but also during the GRC as well. The GRS was a sell-out, attracting more than 60 participants (the expectations set out by the GRC organization were that it would be a success if it attracted more than 35 participants), all of whom were highly enthusiastic about the mentoring and networking opportunities offered by the program.
